title: As late as 1980 there was virtually no in-depth published information on Stevens’s life and thought except for the 1966 volume of his letters edited by his daughter Holly Stevens. But between 1983 and 1991, a flood of biographicallybased works created a body of scholarly knowledge about him that was unprecedented in its concentration and (arguably) unrivalled in its depth among American authors. See especially Peter Brazeau, Parts of a World: Wallace Stevens Remembered: An Oral Biography

container-title: An Encore for Reform: The Old Progressives and the New Deal
title: This brief account of Stevens’s wavering political views closely follows that of Cook, A Reader’s Guide

Stevens’s emphasis on reform over revolution, education over institutional change, and economic experimentation over planning reflects the persistence of Progressive Era values into the 1930s and 1940s

note: The political valence of Stevens’s rhetoric of “change” was shared by other modernists of the period.
title: For a discussion of the theoretical distinction between “politics” and “the political
